{{JoeBidenseries}} [[Image:Joe Biden official portrait crop.jpg|thumb|Joe Biden]] [[Joe Biden]] is the Vice President of the United States and former [[United States Senate|senator]] from the US state of [[Delaware]]. He served in the Senate from 1973 until 2009 and made his [[Joe Biden presidential campaign, 2008|second run]] for President of the United States in the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 presidential election]] as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]]. Biden was announced as Democratic presidential nominee [[Barack Obama]]'s [[running mate]] on August 23, 2008, and was elected Vice President on November 4, 2008. The following are the '''political positions of Joe Biden''' on an assortment of issues. ==Social issues== ===Abortion, stem cell research, cloning=== Joe Biden believes that the ''[[Roe v. Wade]]'' decision should remain intact. He is quoted as saying, "The best policy for our country on the question of abortion is a policy of Government neutrality. Put another way: I do not believe that the government should be involved in making judgments on whether a woman can, or should have an abortion, or â if she chooses to do so â in paying for that abortion."{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} In September 2008, Biden was barred, by [[Joseph Francis Martino]], the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Scranton|bishop of Scranton, Pennsylvania]], from receiving [[Holy Communion]] in the [[diocese]] because of his support for [[abortion rights]].{{cite news |first=David |last=Kirkpatrick |title=Abortion Issue Again Dividing Catholic Votes |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/17/us/politics/17catholics.html?bl&ex=1221883200&en=1e3acb5115249581&ei=5087%0A |work=The New York Times |date=September 16, 2008 |accessdate=September 19, 2008 }} He voted in favor of a 1999 bill to ban in most circumstances [[partial birth abortion]]{{cite web |url = http://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=106&session=1&vote=00340 |title = U.S. Senate Roll Call Votes 106th Congress â 1st Session |accessdate =August 25, 2008 |publisher=[[United States Senate]] }} and on the 2003 [[Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act]].{{cite web |url = http://www3.capwiz.com/c-span/issues/votes/?votenum=402&chamber=S&congress=1081&tally=1 |title = Roll Call Vote No. 402 Tally |accessdate =August 25, 2008 |work=C-SPAN: Congress Guide â Key Votes |publisher=[[C-SPAN]] }} Biden has defended these votes as recently as April 2007.{{cite web |url=http://www.prochoiceamerica.org/elections/statements/biden.html |title=Senator Joe Biden (D-DE) |work=[[NARAL Pro-Choice America]] |accessdate=October 1, 2008 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071213210038/http://www.prochoiceamerica.org/elections/statements/biden.html |archivedate=December 13, 2007}} He has also stated his opposition to federal funding of abortions. [[Image:Senator Joe Biden addresses SEIU.jpg|thumb|Joe Biden at Gallaudet University in Washington DC, USA]] He has joined with Democrats in voting against [[parental notification]] and a ban on abortions on military bases. Biden's record on abortion includes receiving a 100% rating from [[NARAL Pro-Choice America]] in four of the last five years, although he received a 36% as recently as 2003. Biden pledged that he would appoint [[U.S. Supreme Court|Supreme Court]] justices that share his beliefs. He has also stated his opposition to the [[Mexico City Policy]], and voted in favor of the [[Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances Act]] in 1994. Biden supports federal funding for [[embryonic stem cell research]] and voted to expand development and voted against a 1998 ban on [[human cloning]]. ===Capital punishment=== Biden supports capital punishment. He authored the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994, which expanded the number of crimes subject to the federal death penalty. However, he voted against limiting appeals in capital cases and also opposed the rejection of racial statistics in death penalty appeals.{{Citation needed|date=November 2008}} ===Crime=== Joe Biden has been given a 71% approval rating from [[Coalition on Urban Renewal and Education]] (CURE) indicating a pro-rehab record on [[Crime in the United States|crime]]. He voted in support of funding for the [[Community Oriented Policing Services]] (COPS) program. He voted for the [[Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act]], which greatly increased the number of federal crimes punishable by the death penalty and [[Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act#Elimination of inmate education|abolished education grants for prisoners]]. Biden also voted against limiting death penalty appeals.{{cite web|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/2008/Joe_Biden_Crime.htm |title=Joe Biden on Crime |publisher=Ontheissues.org |accessdate=December 11, 2010}} He voted for expanding the definition of [[hate crimes]] and also imposing heavier punishments. Biden supports a [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] registry for [[sex offenders]].{{cite web|url=http://glassbooth.org/explore/index/joe-biden/2/crime-and-punishment/3/ |title=Joe Biden on Crime and Punishment |accessdate=August 25, 2008}} ===Drug law=== [[Image:Senator Joe Biden.jpg|thumb|Joe Biden in [[New Hampshire]]]] Biden favors diverting drug offenders out of the nation's [[Incarceration in the United States|prison system]]. He is ostensibly against making stricter laws for drug offenses, but helped in the creation of a [[Drug Czar]], a government official overseeing all [[War on Drugs|anti-drug operations]]. According to his campaign website, he is for increased penalties against those caught selling drugs within 1000 feet of schools.{{cite news | url=http://www.ontheissues.org/2008/Joe_Biden_Drugs.htm | title=Joe Biden on Drugs }} He was the drafter and chief sponsor of the [[RAVE Act]], a law that aimed to crack down on [[MDMA]]-fueled raves, but which critics called too broad in scope.{{cite news | url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,58663,00.html | publisher=Fox News |title=Raving Lunacy|date=July 25, 2002}} The law, which was later renamed the [[Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act]] of 2003, was additionally controversial because it was passed without public hearing or debate in Congress, attached to an unrelated child protection bill. Critics of the law assert that it has since been used by agents of the [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] to intimidate those organizing rallies and fund-raisers to support drug-law reform.{{cite web |url = http://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle-old/290/dearave.shtml |title = DEA Uses RAVE Act Threats to Block Montana NORML#SSDP Benefit |date = 2003-06=06 |accessdate =August 25, 2008 |publisher=Drug Reform Coordination Network (DRC Net)}} ===Education=== [[Image:Joe Biden, official photo.jpg|thumb|Official color photo of Joe Biden]] Biden received a 91% voting record from the [[National Education Association]] (NEA) showing a pro-teacher union voting record. He supports [[abstinence-only sex education]], is against [[school voucher|student vouchers]] and affirms the [[United States Constitution|Constitutional]] right to [[school prayer|voluntary prayer in school]].{{cite web |url = http://www.ed.gov/legislation/ESEA/sec14510.html |title = Improving America's Schools Act of 1994, SEC. 14510 |accessdate =August 23, 2008 |publisher=US Department of Education }} He voted in favor of Educational Savings Accounts. In regard to the [[No Child Left Behind Act]], Biden stated, {{quote|Classrooms are too big; we need smaller classrooms, period. A lot of teachers are going to be retiring. We need a program where we attract the best and brightest students coming out of our colleges to be teachers, and pay them.{{cite web |url = http://www.ontheissues.org/2008/Joe_Biden_Education.htm |title = Joe Biden on Education |accessdate =August 25, 2008 |publisher=On the Issues }}}} He voted in favor of the Act in 2001, but has subsequently called that vote "a mistake."{{cite news | title = Part I: CNN/YouTube Democratic presidential debate transcript | url = http://www.cnn.com/2007/POLITICS/07/23/debate.transcript/index.html | work=CNN Election Center 2008 | publisher=CNN | date = July 24, 2007 | accessdate =July 26, 2007 }} He has said that the program is underfunding the education system. ===Environment=== He co-sponsored the "Sense of the Senate" resolution calling on the United States to be a part of the United Nations climate negotiations and the "[[Barbara Boxer|Boxer]]-[[Bernie Sanders|Sanders]] Global Warming Pollution Reduction Act", the most stringent climate bill in the [[United States Senate]].Grist Jan 3, 2008 retrieved May 4, 2008 http://www.grist.org/feature/2007/08/29/biden_factsheet/ He voted "Yes" on a $3.1B for emergency oil assistance for [[hurricane]]-hit areas and "No" for drilling in the [[Arctic National Wildlife Refuge]] on national security grounds and defunding renewable and solar energy.On the Issues retrieved May 4, 2008 http://www.ontheissues.org/Senate/Joe_Biden.htm#Energy_+_Oil Biden supports the creation of a new treaty on [[climate change]] that would require emissions reductions from developing countries such as [[Brazil]], India, China, and [[Mexico]]. He has also stated his support for investment in technologies to reduce [[greenhouse gas]] emissions, as well as the creation of a [[Emissions trading|"cap and trade" system]]. Biden supports the promotion of [[renewable energy]], including [[biodiesel]] fuels but not [[ethanol]]. ===Gun issues=== Biden was given an "F" by the [[National Rifle Association]] (NRA) showing an anti-[[gun ownership]] voting record.{{cite web|url=http://www.nrapvf.org/News/Article.aspx?ID=229|title=Unleashed: 20/20 hindsight|date=January 11, 2007|accessdate=August 25, 2008|publisher=National Rifle Association Political Victory Fund}} He supports reinstating a Federal ban on various [[assault weapons|semi-automatic rifles]] and voted against prohibition of lawsuits against gun manufacturers. He has also voted to end what gun-control activists call the "[[Gun show#The "Gun Show Loophole"|gun show loophole]]", stating that no one should be able to walk into a gun show and buy a gun more easily than they could at a normal store. ===Health=== Biden was given a 100% approval rating from the [[American Public Health Association]] (APHA). He supports funding for [[Health care in the United States|health care]] to allow all people access. {{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} ===Homeland security=== After the April 19, 1995 [[Oklahoma City bombing]], a domestic terrorist bomb attack that destroyed the [[Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building]], Biden drafted anti-terrorist legislation, which was ultimately defeated. He later claimed publicly on several occasions that the [[USA PATRIOT Act]] â which eased restrictions on the [[Executive branch]] in the surveillance and detention of those suspected of terrorism or facilitating it â was essentially a duplicate of the anti-terrorist legislation he had drafted years earlier.{{cite web | url = http://www.tnr.com/article/politics/rhetorical-question | title = Rhetorical Question | author=Michael Crowley | publisher=The New Republic | date = October 22, 2001 | accessdate =August 25, 2008}} Biden supported the [[PATRIOT Act]] but voted to limit [[wiretapping]] on the bill. He supports implementing the [[9/11 Commission]]'s recommendations to fight terrorists but voted to preserve [[habeas corpus]] rights to the alleged terror suspects serving in [[Guantanamo Bay detention camp|Guantanamo Bay]]. In the 1990s he voted in favor of 36 vetoed military projects and supports efforts to prevent [[nuclear proliferation]]. He was given a 60% approval rating from the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] reflecting a mixed voting record on [[civil rights]] issues. During a debate on November 15, 2007 Biden clarified the effect of the PATRIOT Act and his continued support for it and his opposition to [[racial profiling]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cfr.org/publication/14820/democratic_debate_transcript_las_vegas_nevada.html?breadcrumb=%2Fbios%2F1451%2Fjoseph_r_biden_jr |title=Democratic Debate Transcript, Las Vegas, Nevada â Council on Foreign Relations|accessdate=August 25, 2008}} ===Immigration=== Biden supported the 2007 [[Comprehensive Immigration Reform Act of 2007|Comprehensive Immigration Reform Bill]]. He supports [[Guest worker program|guest-worker visas]], and the building of a wall along the border as a deterrent to drug trafficking. He voted to provide [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] to [[illegal immigrants]] and supports a path to citizenship.{{cite web | url = http://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=109&session=2&vote=00130#name | title = U.S. Senate: Legislation & Records | accessdate =July 26, 2010 | quote = Biden (D-DE), Yea}} ===Internet privacy and file sharing=== [[CNET.com]] gave Biden a 37.5% in its Technology Issues Voter's Guide.{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/2009-1040-6130830.html?hhTest=1|title=Technology voter guide 2006 â Mapping Congress' voting records | CNET News.com}} They referred to Biden as "Pro-[[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]" and "Pro-[[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]]" in his [[file sharing]] and privacy stances. Biden sponsored a bill that would make it a [[felony]] to record [[internet radio]],{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/Senators-aim-to-restrict-Net,-satellite-radio-recording/2100-1028_3-6149915.html?hhTest=1|title=Senators aim to restrict Net, satellite radio recording - CNET News.com}}{{Failed verification|date=January 2009}} and signed a letter that urged the [[United States Department of Justice]] to prosecute file sharers.http://www.politechbot.com/docs/congress.p2p.letter.081002.pdf Biden also sponsored two bills, the [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d102:s.00266: Comprehensive Counter Terrorism Act] (SB 266) and the [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d102:s.00618: Violent Crime Control Act] (SB 618), both of which contained language seen as effectively banning [[encryption]].{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/cnet/20080824/tc_cnet/83011357831002416338 |title=Joe Biden's pro-RIAA, pro-FBI tech voting record â Yahoo! News |accessdate=August 25, 2008}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ''Crypto'' notes Biden wrote that language into the text of SB 266.{{cite book | last=Levy | first=Steven | authorlink=Steven Levy | title=Crypto: How the Code Rebels Beat the Government, Saving Privacy in the Digital Age | date=2001 | publisher=Viking | location=New York | isbn=0670859508 | page=195}} [[Phil Zimmerman]], creator of [[Pretty Good Privacy]], has said it was SB 266 that "led me to publish PGP electronically for free that year, shortly before the measure was defeated after vigorous protest by civil libertarians and industry groups."{{cite web|url=http://www.philzimmermann.com/EN/essays/index.html |title=Phil Zimmermann on PGP |accessdate=August 25, 2008}} However, Zimmerman later stated in a Slashdot article that he was not specifically criticizing Biden, that he would consider the Senator's "whole body of work" when considering whether to vote for him on the Democratic ticket in 2008, and that "considering the disastrous erosion in our privacy and civil liberties under the (Bush) administration, I feel positively nostalgic about Biden's quaint little non-binding resolution of 1991".{{cite web|url=http://news.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=08/08/26/2126214 |title=Phil Zimmerman on Sen. Biden and 2008 Democratic ticket |accessdate=June 8, 2009}} ===LGBT issues=== Biden voted in favor of the [[Defense of Marriage Act]]{{cite web|url=http://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=104&session=2&vote=00280 |title=U.S. Senate: Legislation & Records|accessdate=August 25, 2008}} but against the [[Federal Marriage Amendment]].{{cite web|url=http://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=109&session=2&vote=00163 |title=U.S. Senate: Legislation & Records|accessdate=August 25, 2008}} He supports states rights to establish [[civil unions]]. Biden voted in favor of "[[Don't Ask Don't Tell]]", but more recently said that it would soon be repealed, adding that "no one asks if you're gay in a [[defensive fighting position|foxhole]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/Joe_Biden.htm |title=Joe Biden on the Issues |publisher=Ontheissues.org |accessdate=December 11, 2010}} Biden favors adding [[sexual orientation]] to the criteria for a [[hate crime]].{{cite web |url = http://www.concordmonitor.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070421/REPOSITORY/704210326/1043/NEWS01|title = Candidates dance at civil unions: Dems shy of marriage; GOP jumps to right |date=April 21, 2007|accessdate =August 25, 2008|publisher=Concord Monitor and New Hampshire Patriot}} ===[[Mormonism]]=== [[Joe Biden]] said;
"I find it preposterous that in 2011 we're debating whether or not a man is qualified or worthy of your vote based on whether or not his religion ... is a disqualifying provision," Biden told an audience at the University of Pittsburgh. "It is not. It is embarrassing and we should be ashamed, anyone who thinks that way," he said in a long response to a student's question about how his own religious faith affected his philosophy of government.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/04/us-usa-campaign-biden-romney-idUSTRE7A371Q20111104 Biden defends Romney's Mormon faith]
===Welfare=== Biden is opposed to the privatization of [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] and was given an 89% approval rating from the [[Alliance for Retired Americans]] (ARA), reflecting a pro-[[senior citizen]] voting record. He voted in support of welfare [[block grant]]s and supports [[welfare reform]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/Economic/Joe_Biden_Welfare_+_Poverty.htm |title=Joe Biden on Welfare & Poverty |publisher=Ontheissues.org |accessdate=December 11, 2010}} ===Women=== In 1994, Biden drafted the [[Violence Against Women Act]], which was signed into law. It provided $1.6 billion to enhance investigation and prosecution of the violent crime perpetrated against women, increased pre-trial detention of the accused, provided for automatic and mandatory restitution of those convicted, and allowed civil redress in cases prosecutors chose to leave unprosecuted. The [[United States Supreme Court]] struck down portions of the VAWA on Constitutional grounds in ''[[United States v. Morrison]]''. Biden has said: "I consider the Violence Against Women Act the single most significant legislation that Iâve crafted during my 35-year tenure in the Senate. Indeed, the enactment of the Violence Against Women Act in 1994 was the beginning of a historic commitment to women and children victimized by [[domestic violence]] and [[sexual assault]]. Our nation has been rewarded for this commitment. Since the Actâs passage in 1994, domestic violence has dropped by almost 50%."{{cite web |url = http://biden.senate.gov/issues/issue/?id=975b0cf4-ce25-42cc-b63d-072fb81e8618 |title = Senator Joe Biden â Senator for Delaware: Issues â Domestic Violence |accessdate =September 8, 2008 |publisher=US Senate |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080822144642/http://biden.senate.gov/issues/issue/?id=975b0cf4-ce25-42cc-b63d-072fb81e8618 |archivedate = August 22, 2008}} He has also said that the Act "empower[s] women to make changes in their lives, and by training police and prosecutors to arrest and convict abusive husbands instead of telling them to take a walk around the block".{{cite web |url = http://biden.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/BidenRecordWomen.pdf |format=PDF|title = Senator Joe Biden Stands Up For Women |accessdate =September 8, 2008 |publisher=US Senate |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080730224418/http://biden.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/BidenRecordWomen.pdf |archivedate = July 30, 2008}} ==Economic issues== [[Image:Joe Biden - World Economic Forum Annual Meeting Davos 2005 Portrait.jpg|thumb|Joe Biden at the [[World Economic Forum]] in [[Davos, Switzerland]]]] ===Agriculture=== "Senator Biden supported the [[Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008|Farm Bill]] and believes that it is a responsible compromise. It is not perfect, but it was the product of lengthy negotiations and passage was essential to our farm economy. For Delaware and the rest of the nation, this bill contains funding and programs that are critical to the future of the family farmer, stewardship of our environment and meeting nutritional needs at a time when food prices are rising."{{cite web |url = http://biden.senate.gov/issues/issue/?id=5df9f66d-9a89-4158-a3c9-66c423a5e802 |title = Senator Joe Biden â Senator for Delaware: Issues â Agriculture |accessdate =September 8, 2008 |publisher=US Senate }} "Senator Biden has been a strong supporter of efforts to combat the problem of [[invasive species]] â plants and animals improperly brought to U.S. shores. Senator Biden feels that these non-native species have the potential to be one of the largest economic and environmental threats in the 21st century. Non-native species alter vegetation, compete with native species, introduce new diseases and interfere with maritime commerce. Conscious of these dangers, Senator Biden continues to support programs aimed at preventing the importation of non-native plants and animals to the United States."{{cite web |url = http://biden.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/BidenOnAgriculture.pdf |format=PDF|title = Senator joe biden on agriculture |accessdate =September 8, 2008 |publisher=US Senate }} "After learning that Russia will start banning chicken imports from 19 plants in the United States" Senator Biden "issued the following statement:" "Russia is once again using [[Non-tariff barriers to trade|non-tariff barriers]] as an excuse to close its markets to American poultry. I am concerned about the effect of this action on Mountaire, a major employer and integral part of our state's agricultural production. Other local poultry processing plants may be targeted. "Russia has repeatedly shown that it is not ready to abide by the rules of international trade. Let's not forget this is part of a bigger picture in which Russia has failed to behave as a responsible member in the international community. Until Russia reverses their recent actionsâboth big and small â its application to join the [[World Trade Organization]] should remain on hold. "The United States must take immediate and necessary steps â just like we did in 2002 -to restore access to this market, which is critical to Delaware's farmers, Delaware's poultry industry and Delaware's economy, which relies heavily on the agricultural industry."{{cite web |url = http://biden.senate.gov/press/press_releases/release/?id=844009C2-8BBD-4DE9-888B-5CC6FF071114 |title = BIDEN Issues Statement on News of Russia's Ban on Chicken Imports |accessdate =September 8, 2008 |publisher=US Senate }} ===Banking=== Biden voted for the [[Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act]] of 2005{{cite web|url=http://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=109&session=1&vote=00044 |title=U.S. Senate: Legislation & Records Home > Votes > Roll Call Vote |publisher=Senate.gov |accessdate=December 11, 2010}} and voted yes on restrictions on personal bankruptcy. ===Energy=== Biden opposes drilling for [[Petroleum|oil]] in the [[Arctic National Wildlife Refuge]] and supports governmental funding to find new [[World energy resources and consumption|energy sources]] as well as upping funding for alternative transportation like [[Amtrak]] and [[mass transit]].{{cite web|url=http://www.anwr.org/Politics/Presidential-Candidates-views-on-ANWR-The-Democrats.php |title=Arctic Power â Arctic National Wildlife Refuge â Presidential Candidates views on ANWR, The Democrats |accessdate=August 25, 2008}} While campaigning for president in 2007, Biden said that, if elected, his top priority would be "[[energy security]]." He has also been quoted as saying "If I could wave a wand, and the Lord said I could solve one problem, I would solve the [[energy crisis]]."Grist Jan 3, 2008 Retrieved May 4, 2008 http://www.grist.org/feature/2007/08/29/biden/ ===Globalization=== Biden was given a 32% approval rating from the [[United States Chamber of Commerce]]. He favors taking burdens off corporations to prevent outsourcing.{{Vague|date=August 2008}} He voted yes on repealing tax subsidies for companies that outsource jobs. {{Citation needed|date=November 2008}} However, he was one of the Democrats to vote for the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA) in 1993.{{cite news | title = Final Senate Vote on NAFTA | url = http://www.citizen.org/print_article.cfm?ID=15960 | publisher=Public Citizen | accessdate =August 22, 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080608182639/http://www.citizen.org/print_article.cfm?ID=15960 |archivedate = June 8, 2008}} Biden was given a 42% approval rating from the [[Cato Institute]], showing a mixed record on [[free trade]]. He opposed the [[Dominican Republic-Central America Free Trade Agreement]] (CAFTA) but supports normalizing relations with China, [[Vietnam]] and the [[Andes|Andean]] nations. He opposes free trade agreements with [[Oman]], Singapore, and [[Chile]]. {{Citation needed|date=November 2008}} ===Labor Unions=== Biden was given a 100% approval rating from the [[AFL-CIO|American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations]]. ===Tax=== Biden is against the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration's]] tax cuts and would "take back one year of the tax cuts for Americans who make over a million dollars a year, and put this money in a dedicated Homeland Security and Public Safety Trust Fund to implement the 9/11 Commission recommendations and invest in law enforcement."{{cite web| title = Issues: Homeland Security| url = http://www.joebiden.com/issues/?id=0004| publisher=Biden's Presidential campaign website|date = August 2, 2007| accessdate =August 2, 2007}}{{Dead link|url=http://www.joebiden.com/issues/?id=0004|date=August 2008}} Biden supports a [[balanced budget amendment]]. Biden cites high health care and [[Oil price increases since 2003|energy costs]] as two major threats to the prosperity of American businesses, and believes that addressing these issues will improve American economic competitiveness.{{cite news | title = Joe Biden for President: Issuesâ | url = http://www.joebiden.com/issues/#0006 | publisher=Biden's Presidential campaign website | date = August 2, 2007 | accessdate =August 2, 2007 }}{{Dead link|url=http://www.joebiden.com/issues/#0006|date=August 2008}} ==Foreign policy== The [[Council on Foreign Relations]] reported on Biden's political positions.{{cite web|url=http://www.cfr.org/bios/1451/joseph_r_biden_jr.html |title=Joseph R. Biden, Jr. â Council on Foreign Relations|accessdate=August 25, 2008}} ===Iraq=== [[Image:Senator Joe Biden speaks to SEIU 2.jpg|thumb|Joe Biden speaking]] In 1990, Joe Biden voted against the first [[Gulf War]] after [[Iraq]] under [[Saddam Hussein]] invaded [[Kuwait]].{{cite news| url=http://online.wsj.com/public/article_print/SB122049148440397625.html }} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} In 1998, Biden expressed support for the use of force against [[Iraq]], and urged a sustained effort to "dethrone" [[Saddam Hussein]] over the long haul.{{cite news | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/inatl/longterm/iraq/stories/iraq111398a.htm | title=Support for U.S. Stance on Iraq Grows | author=Thomas W. Lippman and Bradley Graham |work=Washington Post | date=November 13, 1998}} In 2002, as Chairman of the [[Senate Foreign Relations Committee]], he stated that Saddam Hussein was "a long term threat and a short term threat to our national security" and that United States has "no choice but to eliminate the threat".{{cite news | url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/18381961/page/2 | title=MTP Transcript for April 29, 2007 | author=[[Tim Russert]] | publisher=[[MSNBC]] | date=April 29, 2007 |page=2}} He also said, "I think Saddam either has to be separated from his weapons or taken out of power."Meet the Press August 2002 interview with Tim Russert http://www.michaelmoore.com/mustread/index.php?id=1040 Biden also supported a failed resolution authorizing military action in Iraq only after the exhaustion of diplomatic efforts,{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/24/us/politics/24policy.html|title=New York Times â A Democratic Leader on Foreign Policy, In Iraq and the Balkans | work=The New York Times | first=Michael R. | last=Gordon | date=August 24, 2008 | accessdate=May 22, 2010}} Biden argued that Saddam Hussein possesses [[Chemical warfare|chemical]] and [[Biological warfare|biological weapons]] and is seeking [[Nuclear warfare|nuclear weapons]];[http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=2002_record&docid=cr10oc02-70 AUTHORIZATION OF THE USE OF UNITED STATES ARMED FORCES AGAINST IRAQ] he subsequently voted in favor of authorizing the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|invasion of Iraq]] in 2003. Biden has since said that he believes it was a mistake to support the [[Iraq War]] because it has been mismanaged by the Bush Administration. In 2005, Biden said, "We can call it quits and withdraw from Iraq (but) I think that would be a gigantic mistake, or we can set a deadline for pulling out, which I fear will only encourage our enemies to wait us out â equally a mistake."Joe Biden on Meet the Press 2007 http://www.ontheissues.org/Archive/2007_Meet_the_Press_Joe_Biden.htm Regarding his belief that Iraq maintained stockpiles of [[weapons of mass destruction]], Biden stated in 2007 that inspectors had seen and cataloged the existence of the materials required to make such weapons prior to their expulsion from Iraq and pondered why [[Saddam Hussein]] didn't tell the international community that he had disposed of them. [[Scott Ritter]], the chief [[United Nations weapons inspector]] in Iraq, stated in July 2002 that most chemical and biological agents produced by Iraq would have been neutralized or degraded in storage, encouraging the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee to convene hearings to reassess the threat.Scott Ritter: [http://www.commondreams.org/views02/0721-02.htm Is Iraq a True Threat to the US?] When the committee scheduled hearings in the beginning of August 2002, Ritter stated that "Sen. Joe Biden is running a sham hearing. It is clear that Biden and most of the Congressional leadership have pre-ordained a conclusion that seeks to remove Saddam Hussein from power regardless of the facts, and are using these hearings to provide political cover for a massive military attack on Iraq."[http://accuracy.org/newsrelease.php?articleId=633 Ritter and Von Sponeck on Iraq: Interviews Available] Biden supports a "five-step plan" towards [[Withdrawal of U.S. troops from Iraq|removing troops from Iraq]]. Bush]]'s mandate that one third of all funds be earmarked to abstinence only programs. ===Israel=== Biden is a self-described [[Zionist]].
